title: 106_hr4213
content: The Consumer Mortgage Protection Act of 2000 may be cited as the ``Consumer Mortgage Protection Act of 2000.'' The Consumer Mortgage Protection Act of 2000 aims to provide additional protections for vulnerable consumers in the residential mortgage industry, ensure equity protection for homeowners, streamline mortgage origination regulations, and clarify mortgage broker compensation. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE TRUTH IN LENDING ACT. Amendments to the Truth in Lending Act include changes to the percentage points for transactions secured by first-lien and subordinate-lien security interests in the property. The amendments adjust the thresholds for interest rates in different scenarios. Amendments to the Truth in Lending Act involve changes to lien security interests and thresholds for interest rates in various scenarios. Section 129 of the Act is also amended to reorganize subsections. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to change prepayment penalties based on the timing within the first year of the loan. The penalty amounts are set at 3%, 2%, and 1% of the total loan amount for different prepayment periods. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to adjust prepayment penalties within the first year of the loan, changing the time periods and penalty amounts. Additionally, sections of the Act related to closing costs and restrictions are also modified. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to restrict charging of closing costs for mortgage refinancing within 1 year of the existing mortgage unless certain conditions are met, such as lower annual percentage rate. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include provisions prohibiting creditors from encouraging default on mortgage payments and requiring reporting of payment history to credit bureaus for consumers with mortgages. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to include provisions prohibiting creditors from profiting from foreclosure sales and requiring them to provide a statement of the amount needed to satisfy the debt obligation within 3 business days upon request. Section 130(b) of the Truth in Lending Act is amended to address failures to comply with finance charge or annual percentage rate disclosures, ensuring adjustments are made to prevent overpayment. The Truth in Lending Act is amended to address failures to comply with disclosures by offering a legally effective instrument to modify the transaction. AMENDMENTS TO THE REAL ESTATE SETTLEMENT PROCEDURES ACT. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act is being amended to require a clear itemization of charges imposed directly on the borrower and seller in connection with the settlement. This does not include fees earned by settlement service providers paid by the lender. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act is being amended to require an explanation of how mortgage brokers may be compensated for their services in connection with federally related mortgage loans. Additionally, the Act is amended to clarify that fees likely to be imposed directly on the borrower must be itemized during settlement. The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act is being amended to require a statement in the good faith estimate warning borrowers about the risk of losing their home if they do not meet loan obligations. SEC. 5. FEDERAL PREEMPTION: No State laws can impose requirements or prohibitions on high-cost or high-fee mortgage loans covered by this Act. The Federal Reserve will issue interpretations on whether specific State laws are preempted. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; IMPLEMENTING REGULATIONS. This Act and its amendments will take effect 6 months after enactment. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System and the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will issue necessary regulations within 120 days after enactment.
